ms_process.name: Mass Spectrometry Process
ms_process.correct: In mass spectrometry, molecules are ionised (usually by electron bombardment), accelerated by an electric field, deflected by a magnetic field according to m/z ratio, and detected.

molecules are weighed directly.error: MS measures m/z ratio, not direct mass.
molecules are weighed directly.fix: Ions are separated by mass-to-charge ratio.
molecules are weighed directly.action: The deflection depends on m/z, not mass alone.

no ionisation is needed.error: Ionisation is essential for acceleration and deflection.
no ionisation is needed.fix: Neutral molecules won't respond to electric/magnetic fields.
no ionisation is needed.action: The molecular ion (M‚Å∫) is the ionised molecule.

operates at atmospheric pressure.fix: Vacuum prevents ions colliding with air molecules.
operates at atmospheric pressure.action: Air would scatter the ions and ruin the spectrum.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the MS process.
persistent.action: Four steps: ionise, accelerate, deflect, detect.

molecular_ion_peak.name: Molecular Ion Peak (M‚Å∫)
molecular_ion_peak.correct: The molecular ion peak (M‚Å∫) appears at the m/z value equal to the relative molecular mass of the compound. It represents the intact ionised molecule.

highest peak is always M‚Å∫.error: Base peak (tallest) may not be M‚Å∫.
highest peak is always M‚Å∫.fix: M‚Å∫ is the peak with highest m/z (if present).
highest peak is always M‚Å∫.action: Look at the RIGHT side of the spectrum for M‚Å∫.

M‚Å∫ is always the most intense.error: M‚Å∫ may be weak or absent if molecule fragments easily.
M‚Å∫ is always the most intense.fix: Stable molecules show strong M‚Å∫; unstable ones may not.
M‚Å∫ is always the most intense.action: Base peak = most intense. M‚Å∫ = highest m/z.

M‚Å∫ shows the mass of one atom.error: M‚Å∫ is the whole molecule, not one atom.
M‚Å∫ shows the mass of one atom.fix: The molecular ion is the complete molecule minus one electron.
M‚Å∫ shows the mass of one atom.action: M‚Å∫ = whole molecule with a positive charge.

persistent.gap: You're confusing M‚Å∫ with base peak.
persistent.action: M‚Å∫ = highest m/z (molecular mass). Base peak = tallest peak.

fragmentation_patterns.name: Fragmentation Patterns
fragmentation_patterns.formula: Bonds break to form fragment ions
fragmentation_patterns.correct: The molecular ion can break apart into smaller fragment ions. The m/z values of these fragments reveal structural information about the molecule.

all molecules fragment the same way.error: Fragmentation patterns are characteristic of structure.
all molecules fragment the same way.fix: Different functional groups give different fragmentation.
all molecules fragment the same way.action: Use fragments to identify functional groups.

fragmentation is random.error: Bonds break at predictable weak points.
fragmentation is random.fix: Weaker bonds (like C-C next to C=O) break preferentially.

fragments are neutral.fix: M‚Å∫ ‚Üí fragment‚Å∫ + neutral piece. Only fragment‚Å∫ is detected.
fragments are neutral.action: The detector only sees charged species.

persistent.action: M‚Å∫ breaks into charged fragment (detected) + neutral piece (not detected).

base_peak.name: Base Peak
base_peak.correct: The base peak is the most intense (tallest) peak in the spectrum and is assigned a relative intensity of 100%. All other peaks are measured relative to this.

base peak is always M‚Å∫.error: Base peak is the tallest; M‚Å∫ is the highest m/z.
base peak is always M‚Å∫.fix: They may or may not be the same peak.
base peak is always M‚Å∫.action: If M‚Å∫ is very stable, it might also be the base peak.

base peak is always at m/z = 0.error: Base peak can be at any m/z value.
base peak is always at m/z = 0.fix: It's wherever the most abundant ion appears.
base peak is always at m/z = 0.action: Find the tallest peak‚Äîthat's the base peak.

relative intensity is absolute counts.error: Intensity is relative to the base peak (100%).
relative intensity is absolute counts.fix: A peak at 50% is half the height of the base peak.
relative intensity is absolute counts.action: All intensities are percentages relative to base peak.

persistent.gap: You're confusing base peak with M‚Å∫.
persistent.action: Base peak = tallest = 100%. M‚Å∫ = highest m/z = molecular mass.

common_fragments.name: Common Fragment Ions
common_fragments.correct: Common fragment ions include: CH‚ÇÉ‚Å∫ (15), C‚ÇÇH‚ÇÖ‚Å∫ (29), CHO‚Å∫ (29), C‚ÇÇH‚ÇÉO‚Å∫ (43), C‚ÇÉH‚Çá‚Å∫ (43), OH‚Å∫ (17), and loss of H‚ÇÇO (M-18).

all fragments have odd masses.error: Masses can be odd or even.
all fragments have odd masses.fix: The nitrogen rule helps predict odd/even patterns.

fragments only come from C-C bonds.fix: C-O, C-N, and other bonds also fragment.
fragments only come from C-C bonds.action: Consider all bond types when interpreting.

fragment masses are arbitrary.fix: Each mass corresponds to specific atom combinations.
fragment masses are arbitrary.action: Learn common masses: 15 (CH‚ÇÉ), 29 (CHO or C‚ÇÇH‚ÇÖ), etc.

persistent.gap: You don't know common fragment masses.

m_plus_one.name: M+1 Peak
m_plus_one.correct: The M+1 peak (one mass unit above M‚Å∫) is due to molecules containing ¬π¬≥C instead of ¬π¬≤C. Its intensity relative to M‚Å∫ indicates the number of carbon atoms.

M+1 is an error.fix: It comes from naturally occurring ¬π¬≥C (1.1% abundance).

all molecules show the same M+1.error: M+1 depends on number of carbons.

M+1 indicates nitrogen.fix: Nitrogen affects odd/even M‚Å∫ mass, not M+1.

persistent.action: M+1 from ¬π¬≥C. Intensity √∑ 1.1 ‚âà number of carbons.

mass_calculation.name: Calculating Molecular Mass
mass_calculation.correct: The m/z value of the molecular ion peak directly gives the relative molecular mass (Mr) of the compound, assuming z = 1 (singly charged).

add all peak values.fix: M‚Å∫ is the intact molecule; fragments are pieces.
add all peak values.action: Find the highest m/z peak (M‚Å∫) for Mr.

divide by charge first.action: Assume singly charged unless told otherwise.

Mr is the base peak value.error: Base peak may be a fragment.
Mr is the base peak value.fix: Mr = M‚Å∫ (highest m/z), not base peak.
Mr is the base peak value.action: Distinguish M‚Å∫ (highest m/z) from base peak (tallest).

persistent.gap: You're reading the wrong peak for Mr.
persistent.action: Mr = m/z of M‚Å∫ peak = highest m/z value in spectrum.

spectrum_interpretation.name: Interpreting Mass Spectra
spectrum_interpretation.correct: Interpretation involves: finding M‚Å∫ (Mr), identifying the base peak, recognising common fragment losses (M-15, M-18, M-29), and deducing structural features.

only M‚Å∫ matters.fix: M‚Å∫ tells mass; fragments tell structure.
only M‚Å∫ matters.action: Both M‚Å∫ and fragments are needed for full interpretation.

spectra can't distinguish isomers.fix: Different structures give different fragment patterns.
spectra can't distinguish isomers.action: Same Mr, different fragments = different isomers.

interpretation requires exact formulas.fix: M-18 suggests H‚ÇÇO loss (alcohol/acid). M-29 suggests CHO loss.
interpretation requires exact formulas.action: Learn characteristic losses for functional groups.

persistent.action: Steps: find M‚Å∫, identify fragments, deduce structure from patterns.

sentences.text: In mass spectrometry, molecules are first {{d1}} by removing an electron to form positive ions, typically using {{d2}} bombardment.

ms_principles.title: Applying MS Principles
ms_principles.instructions: Apply your understanding of mass spectrometry to these scenarios.

sentences.text: The stability of M‚Å∫ determines its {{d1}} in the spectrum. Branched alkanes show {{d2}} M‚Å∫ peaks than straight-chain isomers.
